page.title: 09Language
page.content: One pecularity of the Doric is the regular use of F for WH. "Who" becomes "Fa"" "what" becomes "fit". There is a jocular sentence "Fa fuppit the fite fulpie?" which is translated "Who whipped the white puppy (whelp)?" Probably the most distinctive vowel change is "ee" for "oo". Moon" becomes "Meen", "soon" becomes "seen" and "broom" "breem" etc. Another noticeable characteristic is the profuse use of diminutive affixes and prefixes.Especially prevalent is an affectionate use of "ie" diminutive - man-mannie, lass-lassie, wife-wifie, cat-cattie etc. The diminutive "wee" is also used and "bit" is similarly common as is the suffix "ick". These can be combined; the extreme example being "a wee bit lassickie".
